timeline.bodyText: Is context required in exit spans? I can't get the producer's instrumentation to work.
timeline.author: hectorespert

replies.bodyText:
Without looking too much into the implementation, what do you mean you can't get it to work? What's not working?

If you use log_level=DEBUG, can you see whether the instrumentation is applied? You should see a Method match for instrumentation RabbitMQProducerInstrumentation indicating that the matchers found the method it was looking for
Can you make sure the producer method is invoked when you expect it to be invoked in the test? If so, you can add a System.out and make sure the advice code runs when it is called as well.
Can you see whether the trace context headers are added to the message? If not, it may be read-only at this point
Try to print out the message headers on the receiver advice
replies.author: eyalkoren

replies.bodyText:

replies.bodyText: That could be because you did not call span.end() in RabbitProducerAdvice#afterBasicPublish()

Yes, seems that it is the error 🤦
Thank you for your patience

timeline.message: try to modify the basic properties
use separate module for integ. tests
add logging & make schema validation less verbose
make it work again & integ tests for v3,4,5

migrate tests to new architecture & remove mock
allow advice class delegation on runtime instr.

timeline.bodyText:
What functionality is impacted by that? Will RabbitMQ be visible as part of the service map?
What's preventing the capturing of the address? Maybe summarize the problems in a follow-up issue.
timeline.author: felixbarny

replies.bodyText:
What functionality is impacted by that? Will RabbitMQ be visible as part of the service map?

For my side, I don't know if any feature is affected. I used the same solution that use the kafka plugin.

What's preventing the capturing of the address? Maybe summarize the problems in a follow-up issue.

There isn't any attribute in the instrumented methods that allows obtain the address directly. I don't know if it can be obtained using other methods.
replies.author: hectorespert

replies.bodyText:
What functionality is impacted by that? Will RabbitMQ be visible as part of the service map?

The address is not required for the service map, only for the SIEM integration.

There isn't any attribute in the instrumented methods that allows obtain the address directly. I don't know if it can be obtained using other methods.

If you know the address when the channel is created, you can store it in a map (channel object ---> address) and when the method is called, get it through the @Advice.This reference in the instrumented method.
replies.author: eyalkoren

replies.bodyText:
I see. Maybe one day I'll remember. Thanks for explaining again 😉
So I would say it's not too critical at the moment.
replies.author: felixbarny

replies.bodyText: There isn't even a need to use a map in this case as we can use Channel.getConnection(), I've implemented that in the t commit.
replies.author: SylvainJuge

timeline.bodyText: What does that means? How come we don't look for specific types?
timeline.author: eyalkoren

replies.bodyText:
It's because only known types explicitly get instrumented via DynamicTransformer. See ConnectionInstrumentation.
Also note that the service descriptor META-INF/services/co.elastic.apm.agent.sdk.ElasticApmInstrumentation does not contain ChannelInstrumentation.
replies.author: felixbarny

replies.bodyText: We could probably create a dedicated subclass for those "instrumentations applied at runtime", that would probably make things a bit more obvious instead of repeating this comment.
replies.author: SylvainJuge

replies.bodyText: I understand why Consumer instrumentation is dynamic, but why does the Channel instrumentation needs to be dynamic? Isn't there a close number of implementations (all containing the String Channel)?
replies.author: eyalkoren

replies.bodyText: has been covered in the last commit.
replies.author: SylvainJuge

timeline.bodyText: without this, it works only with advice that is directly within the instrumentation class, and not delegated to it's own class.
timeline.author: SylvainJuge

replies.bodyText: Can we do this caching based on advice class names only, instead of instrumentation classes and their instantiation here? I mean that ensureInstrumented will be done directly on advice class names
replies.author: eyalkoren

timeline.author: eyalkoren
eyalkoren

timeline.bodyText:
Verify transaction details - type, name.
Verify context propagation:

both transactions should have the same trace ID
receiver side transaction's parent should be the send span

You can reuse the utility methods for such checks.
timeline.author: eyalkoren

timeline.bodyText:
I am not sure I understand why this is required instead of simple type matching for Channel implementations.
However, since we already have this instrumentation, let's use it to store channel destination metadata (address and port) and use it to fill the send span destination details in the basicPublish instrumentation. Looks like very little is left in order to collect this info.
timeline.author: eyalkoren

replies.bodyText: Or what you did - use com.rabbitmq.client.Channel#getConnection, much simpler 😄
replies.author: eyalkoren

timeline.message:
Update docs/supported-technologies.asciidoc

improve documentation

Co-authored-by: eyalkoren <41850454+eyalkoren@users.noreply.github.com>
transaction & span naming consistent with Kafka

timeline.bodyText:
I actually prefer the former. This name doesn't indicate it is RabbitMQ.
My comment about aligning names was more about the fact that the exchange/queue is missing from the receive transaction. In Kafka, I relied on the class name to indicate it is Kafka, so suggesting:

  
    
      
        Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                            .withName("Channel#basicPublish to ")
          
          
            
                            .withName("RabbitMQ message SEND to ")
timeline.author: eyalkoren
eyalkoren

timeline.bodyText:
If tracer.currentTransaction() != null, we should probably capture this as a message receive span.
For example, when there is an active transaction that is synching on an async read from queue (like in send-reply scenario).
Requires a test as well. JMS and Kafka rely on send-reply scenarios for that.
timeline.author: eyalkoren
eyalkoren
eyalkoren
eyalkoren

timeline.bodyText:
We should only capture headers on message read when starting a transaction.
Capturing outgoing headers in not aligned with other messaging plugins nor HTTP client plugins.
(Similarly if we decide to capture body in the future).
timeline.author: eyalkoren

timeline.author: eyalkoren

timeline.bodyText: [minor] why not null for no exchange?
timeline.author: eyalkoren
eyalkoren

timeline.bodyText: Should contain the exchange in the resource name
timeline.author: eyalkoren

replies.bodyText: For polling, the exchange name is only known when there is a message, thus that would use two different names for the cases with/without a response, whereas it's the same polling operation. Also, I found it was more consistent with the "use the queue name when available, exchange name otherwise".
replies.author: SylvainJuge

replies.bodyText:
My bad, I read it too quickly, here it's about the resource name, not the span name. Thus we should have:

rabbitmq for polling when there is no message
rabbitmq/${exchange} for polling when there is a message

We do not include queue name in resource name due to potentially high cardinality.
Also, that means that a successful message is being captured with queue name, and exchange name is visible in resource name, which could help to configure filtering using either queue name and exchange name.
replies.author: SylvainJuge
